page.title: 01Aigas & The River Beauly
page.content: The section is divided by a valley which runs diagonally from north east to SW. Along its floor flows the River Beauly which is flanked by two roads; the A831 on its northern side and a minor one on the south. On the latter the Inverness bus terminates its run at the hamlet of Hughton. To the west amidst rough upland crags, the highest point BAD A'CHLAMHAIN (306m) looms above Aigas hamlet. Almost all of the northern part is covered by coniferous forest, dominated by Scots Pine & Spruce. S & SE holds quite a number of rough grazing fields, with a belt of coniferous woodland. The grazing land is used for rearing beef cattle & sheep; the grass is not sufficiently nutritious for dairy herds. Forestry is an important source of employment; so too is tourism. This beautiful and
